title: When Tryndamere and Fiora get into a dual.

that's why you deflect it not block it. puts much less stress on the blade. and on sabers and rapiers, which are designed for parrying and deflecting. it would work.

well sparks and such depends on the material. but remember that's an anime. partical effects are par for the course. but if you look see how Saber's blade looks like its bouncing around a lot more? that is showing her letting the blade be knocked aside by the great sword. her blade is still taking the brunt but she's deflecting not reflecting.

well like i said swords can spark... it just means that  its made horribly and will shatter in your hands very soon.

the sparks mean there's still slag left in the metal which exponentially decreases the strength of the blade.

You have learned much Young Padawan.

In either case, primarily it's speculation because the gif moves far too fast to see if she is meant to be parrying or not.  However, just watching the blue blur that I would assume is the blade, she seems to have multiple points where she tries to impact the sword at a perpendicular angle. A rapier, while designed to parry and deflect, does not do either very well vertically (or perpendicularly to be more precise).  It is meant to bend and give-way enough to allow for the glancing nature of fencing maneuvers.  That's why in fencing when you parry it is done with a simple push to the side, not with a full swing of the sword.  In fact, an actual power-maneuver is to simply swing your sword at the opponent's sword to knock it away, and if done correctly is more than enough to knock someone off-balance.

Is it stands, though, a sword like that would not be able to perform such actions against a cleaver such as that.  That's actually one of the reasons two-handed swords such as a Zweihander and Claymore were created - they were big enough to actually render the bulky armor knights wore practically worthless in that that was their sole purpose.  Cleaving armor.  They were much to unwieldy and slow to justify against someone unarmored, but as heavy armor was made to deflect the swords of the past - generally short swords and the like - technology evolved to next best such defenses. Then came your light, piercing weapons - rapiers, foils, etc. - not because they could stand against such weapons but because they were far faster and more precise, meaning while your enemy is swinging what was practically 7 pounds of dead, air-resistant weight, you had plenty of time to side-step and jab them in the throat.

I actually don't believe it's even suggested to try just purely deflecting such a weapon in that manner. It's easier and safer just to side-step, and it keeps you from being knocked off-balance.

But this is entirely ignoring that it's anime and it's so wildly inaccurate that 14 year old stick-girls fire the equivalent of a Barrett with one hand all the goddamn time.

While in bikinis.
To be fair, this fight is a tad bit inacurate to the ACTUAL interpretation, her sword being a longsword and not a Rapier. Excalibur to be precise
Japanese fascination with Western mythology tied in with their utter misinterpretation and lack of understanding of it makes for some, uh... oddities.
the sparks come from the grinding of materials. if its being deflected, it will grind against the flat of saber's blade, creating sparks

My avatar is just a image that I liked. Because that is what avatars are. I'm pretty sure that Laughing Fish is not actually a shark that is forever laughing, and I don't think that the one person I saw is in fact a tree. Their avatars are just that avatars, images that they liked.

And what do you mean I type in a girlish way? I honestly can't tell the difference really.

But no, I do not pretend to be a girl.
